surgery_fear.objection: I'm scared of surgery and the risks involved
surgery_fear.authentic_response: That's a completely normal and healthy concern. Surgery is a serious decision. Let's talk through the specific risks for YOUR situation, what we do to minimize them, and compare that to the risks of not addressing this. We'll also discuss all non-surgical options first - surgery should only happen when it's truly the best path forward for your goals.
surgery_fear.validation: Acknowledge fear as legitimate and wise, not something to dismiss
surgery_fear.approach: Provide specific risk data, safety protocols, and ensure patient feels in control of decision

recovery_time.objection: I can't afford to be off work/away from responsibilities for that long
recovery_time.authentic_response: Let's talk about what recovery really looks like for your specific procedure and situation. Many patients are surprised that they can [return to desk work within X weeks/modify activities sooner than expected]. We'll also discuss what continuing with your current condition means for your long-term ability to work. Sometimes the question isn't whether you can afford the recovery time, but whether you can afford not to address this.
recovery_time.approach: Provide realistic timeline, discuss accommodations, compare to progressive deterioration scenario

cost_concern.objection: I'm worried about the cost and what insurance will cover
cost_concern.authentic_response: Financial concerns are absolutely valid and important to address upfront. Our team will verify your exact coverage and out-of-pocket costs before you make any decisions. We'll also discuss payment options if needed. What I don't want is for you to suffer for years because of cost uncertainty - let's get you real numbers so you can make an informed decision.
cost_concern.validation: Treat financial concerns as legitimate, not obstacles to overcome
cost_concern.approach: Commit to transparency, provide resources for financial clarity, discuss value of quality of life

want_second_opinion.objection: I think I want to get a second opinion before deciding
want_second_opinion.authentic_response: I absolutely support that - in fact, I encourage it for any major procedure. A second opinion can give you confidence in your decision either way. I'm happy to provide all your imaging and records to make that easy. What matters most is that you feel completely confident in your treatment plan, whether that's with me or another surgeon.
want_second_opinion.approach: Make process easy, demonstrate confidence without defensiveness, focus on patient's best interest

age_concern.objection: Maybe I'm too old for surgery / Maybe I should just live with this
age_concern.authentic_response: Age is just one factor we consider, and it's more about your overall health and goals than a number. I've had [70/80] year-old patients who've done beautifully because they were motivated and healthy. The real question is: what quality of life do you want, and is this condition preventing that? You deserve to live without pain regardless of your age.
age_concern.validation: Challenge ageist assumptions while respecting concern
age_concern.approach: Focus on functional goals and quality of life, provide age-appropriate success stories

heard_horror_stories.objection: My friend/relative had a bad experience with [this procedure/orthopedic surgery]
heard_horror_stories.authentic_response: I'm sorry to hear that - complications and poor outcomes do happen, and they're scary to hear about. Every patient and situation is different, though. Let me explain what we do specifically to prevent those complications, our actual complication rates, and what makes your situation unique. I'd also be happy to connect you with patients who've had positive experiences if that would help.
heard_horror_stories.validation: Acknowledge that bad outcomes happen and fear is justified
heard_horror_stories.approach: Provide specific data, explain risk mitigation, offer patient testimonials or references

try_conservative_first.objection: Shouldn't I try [physical therapy/injections/other conservative treatment] first?
try_conservative_first.authentic_response: That's often exactly the right approach, and I'm glad you're thinking about less invasive options. Let's review what you've already tried and discuss whether additional conservative treatment makes sense for your specific condition. Sometimes we've already exhausted those options, but if there's something we haven't tried that could help, we should absolutely do that first.
try_conservative_first.validation: Affirm preference for conservative care when appropriate
try_conservative_first.approach: Review treatment history, explain when conservative care works vs. when it won't address underlying problem

can_wait.objection: Can't I just wait and see if it gets better?
can_wait.authentic_response: Sometimes that's reasonable, depending on your condition. But let's be clear about what 'wait and see' means for YOUR situation. Is this condition likely to improve on its own, stay the same, or get worse? What's the impact on your life while you wait? And could waiting make treatment more difficult later? I want you to make this decision with full information about what waiting really means.
can_wait.validation: Respect desire to avoid unnecessary intervention
can_wait.approach: Provide honest prognosis, discuss risks of delay specific to their condition, ensure informed decision

educational.title: Why Your Knee Pain Gets Worse at Night
educational.hook: If your knee hurts more when you're trying to sleep, here's what's actually happening...
educational.body: During the day, movement pumps fluid away from your joints. At night, that fluid accumulates, increasing pressure and inflammation. Plus, fewer distractions mean you notice pain more. Here's what helps: elevate your leg above heart level, ice for 15 minutes before bed, and avoid eating inflammatory foods after 6pm. If this happens 3+ nights per week, it's time to get it checked.

educational.title: The 30-Second Rotator Cuff Test You Can Do at Home
educational.hook: Think you might have a rotator cuff injury? Try this test right now...
educational.body: Stand up and raise both arms straight out to the sides at shoulder height. Now, rotate your thumbs down toward the floor and have someone push down gently on your wrists while you resist. If you feel sharp pain, significant weakness, or can't hold the position, that's a positive empty can test - a strong indicator of rotator cuff damage. This doesn't replace a professional exam, but it tells you if you need one soon.
educational.cta: Positive test? Don't wait - rotator cuff tears get worse over time. Schedule an appointment today.
educational.visual_notes: Demonstrate the test step-by-step with clear angles, show both positive and negative results

educational.title: Why Your Hip Pain Might Actually Be Your Back
educational.hook: Treating your hip but nothing's working? Your back might be the real problem...
educational.body: Your L4 and L5 nerve roots send signals down to your hip and outer thigh. When these nerves get compressed - from a herniated disc or spinal stenosis - you feel it as hip pain. The giveaway: true hip pain hurts in the groin and with rotation. Referred pain from your back hurts on the outside and shoots down your leg. We see patients waste months treating the wrong area.
educational.cta: Getting the diagnosis right matters. Our comprehensive exam identifies the true source - schedule your evaluation.
educational.visual_notes: Use spine and hip anatomy overlay, show pain pattern differences with graphics

pricing_psychology.comparison_anchoring: Compare cost of treatment now vs cost of delayed treatment (worse injury, more invasive surgery needed, lost work time)
pricing_psychology.time_value: Emphasize faster recovery options as time savings - 'back to work 3 weeks sooner' - time is money for patients
pricing_psychology.financing_normalization: Present payment plans as standard, not special - 'most patients use our 0% financing' removes stigma
